title: 109_hr5219
content: The Act titled "Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2006" establishes an Inspector General for the Judicial Branch under Part III of title 28, United States Code. The "Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2006" establishes the Office of Inspector General for the Judicial Branch. The Inspector General is appointed by the Chief Justice of the United States and conducts investigations into misconduct within the Judicial Branch, excluding the Supreme Court. The Office of Inspector General for the Judicial Branch, established by the "Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2006," has the power to conduct investigations, audits, and recommend changes in laws or regulations governing the Judicial Branch. The Inspector General can obtain information from various governmental agencies and entities to prevent and detect waste, fraud, and abuse. The Office of Inspector General for the Judicial Branch, established by the "Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2006," has the power to conduct investigations, audits, and recommend changes in laws or regulations governing the Judicial Branch. It can require witnesses to testify and produce documents, administer oaths, and employ officers and employees. The Inspector General for the Judicial Branch has the authority to set pay rates, obtain services, enter into contracts for audits and studies, and make necessary payments. They are required to make an annual report to the Chief Justice and Congress on the Office's activities. The Inspector General for the Judicial Branch has the authority to report to Congress and the Chief Justice on Office activities, including sensitive matters. They must promptly inform the Attorney General of any suspected violations of federal law. Whistleblower protection is also provided for employees in the Judicial Branch. Employees in the Judicial Branch are protected from retaliation for providing information on potential violations of federal law or misconduct by a judge or another employee. In case of a violation, the employee can seek relief through a civil action. The Judicial Branch has an Inspector General to oversee potential violations of federal law or misconduct by employees.
